header.title: Far-Left Momentum activists oust another moderate local Labour leader
header.subtitle: ACTIVISTS from the far-Left group Momentum have ousted another moderate local Labour leader.
header.postText: In a further sign hardliners are tightening their grip on the party, Tim Dwelly quit as Labour group leader on Cornwall Council.', 'A party member for more than three decades, he declared it was “no longer Labour”.', 'Momentum activists said “Dwelly’s resignation is no bad thing” and that it showed the group was winning “the battle for the soul of Labour”.', 'He is the latest in a series of senior local Labour chiefs ousted by militants.', 'They include Haringey Council leader Claire Kober, who left after accusing sections of the party of “sexism” and “bullying”.', 'Momentum has also moved to seize control of “moderate” Labour councils in Manchester and Leeds.', 'Mr Dwelly wrote on Facebook: “I feel the Labour Party I joined all those years ago is no longer Labour. Many of those running the party in Cornwall today only joined to take it to the far-Left.', '“Many of them are now actively attacking elected Labour councillors like me. I have been told bluntly that they want to get rid of me.”', 'His departure comes after infighting involving the chair of Truro and Falmouth Momentum, who resigned citing “lies, scaremongering and slander”.', 'Tory Plymouth MP Johnny Mercer said: “Across the country the hard-Left are taking over Labour, hounding out moderates.', '“The hard-left who have infiltrated Labour support massive council tax hikes and disruptive bin strikes – and working people would always pay the price with higher taxes and worse services.', '“Only the Conservatives are working to build a stronger, fairer economy, while Labour are only interested in playing politics, not delivering for people.”', 'This May, some 151 councils across England will hold elections, including all 32 London boroughs.

commentThread.commentText: The more Momentum gain control of Labour the more voters will switch away from them.

replies.commentText: I wish that were true but sadly many labour supporters simply follow the historic family vote, i.e. "we've always voted labour", the brains are in short supply.

Nah, the traditional white working class "we've always voted Labour" are no doubt wising up to where this is headed, particularly as Labour no longer represents them and prefers to forget about their children being raped en masse by grooming gangs. Why, they even sacked an MP for daring to bring it up in case they lost the m-uslim vote in their Labour controlled areas. What kind of Labour party is that which kowtows to an alien ideology and dare not criticise it even when it is doing abhorrent things?

Goeie dag Meneer, sounds like you been there.  I spent some time in both RSA and Zim, so know where you're coming from.  As for FPTP, you are spot on.  Strange isn't it that we force the devolved nations to use PR, yet the English are stuck with the tired old FPTP.  One day, hopefully soon, the English democratic deficit will be sorted out.

Why, oh why, do we constantly repeat the mistakes of the past. The geriatric fool Corbyn is totally demented if he thinks it will be any better this time around.

From my working class background my parents would, without a thought, vote Liebour, however whilst Corbyn and others in the party are moving towards communism and the state, i can not bring myself to consider them as a party of choice. I hope that its member will change the Labour party´ s direction and again provide an alternative option to working class families.
Corbyn represents Marxist filth and the sooner he’s got rid of the better for the Labour Party.

Our present politicians are known to be 'dangerous' for our country's people, economy, security and social cohesion, Momentum supported Labour politicians would be absolutely 'cataclysmic' for people both locally and nationally, wrecking our economy, security and social cohesion which although not good at present, would deteriorate to levels bordering on anarchy.  The people of this country 'are between a rock and a very hard place' unless a new political party is formed to represent us without the 'baggage' of party dogma.

I hope that in the forthcoming local elections, millions of people will vote for any candidate who is NOT Labour or Tory. From experience we know they are all as bad as each other, but a massive vote against Labour and Tory might make our MPs of all parties see what might happen to them in the next general election.
If momentum gain in the local elections, then, when bills go up they can only blame themselves.  They will have elected them.

Fat lot of good 'the Soul of Labour' will do them when the 'Body of Voters' disappears - which it will! Momentum comprises a violent, vicious, voluble minority of which traditional Labour voters want no part - these will wander over to the Tories, or form another party completely.
The cancer spreads.
Death to momentum.
